subject: Re: class isolation and class order for testing
msgSnippet: ... Seems sound, because that s the definition of the interface, anyway, if that s what is used there. An interface mustn t have anything to do with
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Nat Pryce" <nat.pryce@...> wrote:

> I usually use mock objects where the real object has a plug-in point
> at which it talks through an interface to another object. The test
> needs to express how the object calls out through the interface, not
> how the object and one specific implementation work.

Seems sound, because that's the definition of the interface, anyway,
if that's what is used there. An interface mustn't have anything to do
with implementation, at all.

So how and where do the tests express how the object calls out through
the interface?
Maybe in the mock implementation by doing some assertions on the
arguments of the interface-method? So are you allowed to put part of
your assertions other than the test method-body in JUnit?

Thanks for sharing your experiences, Nat!
Csaba
